1. Your full name: Mrs. Thomas C.J.
2. Your address: Box 66, Johns, Sask.
3. Date: Aug. 17, 1953.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Johns, North Dakota.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Hovels, Farmer.
6. Where did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) Aug./1902.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Edwards, Colborne, 1878-1902.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you could not or you do not know.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (If you could not or you do not know, you may not answer this question.)

He was married the 1st July 1903 and lived at Brandon until 1907 when we came to our homestead at 1907 in the Selkirk District and we still live there at present in summer and in winter in Brandon.

I had 2 children for Bob - Fowler who farmed the land with my husband.

We arrived at Brandon, then drove to our homestead with a big team of oxen on wagon and loaded down with flour, provisions and supplies.

Mrs. Hovels, my mother-in-law and myself were the only women near us within a mile. We had to travel years that way without water.
11. What did you friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Eastern Canada? They all thought it was a good idea.

9. I intended to make my home in the West and the West is the place for me.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

9. I traveled with a neighbor woman named Ada.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

C. P. R. from Brandon to Moose Jaw, then my brother met me with horse and cart and took me home with him to the farm at Willow Creek.

14. Describe your journey West. (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.)

I met several people on the train coming west going to different points with the same intention of settling their homes here. The train was crowded and very crowded. To stop on the way was not easy, they seemed to stop quite often. Once when they stopped a couple of weeks, the passengers got off and walked about thirty yards nearby.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My brother Bill and family who had been married a year delivered the new William Smith in July 1903.

16. Where did you settle or take up land/my husband's occupation? I settled in Brandon.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

July 1903 - Aug 1903

Air Wilson farm for 10 months, Brandon, Man.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I helped at home on the farm after my husband returned from school in Ontario. After he was married and lived in Brandon, March 1903 - 1907, then moved to our homestead in 1907 and it is still on farms today in Redvers, spending the past 3 winters in Saskatoon.
11. What did you feel before and during the trip?
   - I felt anxious about the journey and the long distance.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?
   - I traveled with my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   - We used a horse-drawn carriage.

14. What was the most memorable part of the journey?
   - The most memorable part was seeing the vast prairie landscape.

15. How did you first arrive in Western Canada?
   - We arrived by train from Brandon to Winnipeg.

16. Where did you settle or take up lastingly in Western Canada?
   - We settled in Brandon, Manitoba.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Western Canada.
   - We also lived in Winnipeg for a short time.

18. When did you arrive in Western Canada?
   - We arrived in 1903.

19. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?
   - Before coming to Western Canada, we earned a living as farmers in Ontario.

20. How did you earn a living after coming to Western Canada?
   - After coming to Western Canada, we continued farming in Manitoba.
13. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Glad to get the friendly letters from friends and relatives.

20. If you married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone ever come to Chattanooga because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, did they settle near where you settled?

My two brothers, Robert and John, both moved to Nebraska in 1894.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

In 1909 my husband moved away helping build the church in Johnson City. We built a kitchen addition on our first house. We had no stove and had to cook over an open fire. We made our own flour. In 1910 we bought a new house. We moved into the new house on one side and left the old house. The old house was sold by the owner. They were very kind to us.

24. Did you travel about much? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes, we traveled quite a bit. We visited my mother-in-law in Tennessee twice a year. We also went to see my children in Idaho twice a year.

25. What was the most difficult thing you faced when moving to Tennessee?

Moving to Tennessee was very difficult. We had to leave everything behind and start anew. It was hard to adjust to the new environment and lifestyle.
